# United States presidential line of succession

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to: navigation, search

The **United States presidential line of succession** is the order in which
persons may become or act as [President of the United
States](/wiki/President_of_the_United_States "President of the United States")
if the [incumbent](/wiki/Incumbent "Incumbent") President becomes
[incapacitated](/wiki/Capacity_\(law\) "Capacity \(law\)"), dies, resigns, or
is removed from office (by
[impeachment](/wiki/Impeachment_in_the_United_States "Impeachment in the
United States") by the [House of
Representatives](/wiki/House_of_Representatives_of_the_United_States "House of
Representatives of the United States") and subsequent
[conviction](/wiki/Conviction "Conviction") by the
[Senate](/wiki/Senate_of_the_United_States "Senate of the United States")).
The line of succession is set by the United States Constitution and the
[Presidential Succession Act of 1947](/wiki/Presidential_Succession_Act
"Presidential Succession Act")[1] as subsequently amended to include newly
created cabinet offices. The succession follows the order of [Vice
President](/wiki/Vice_President_of_the_United_States "Vice President of the
United States"), [Speaker of the House of
Representatives](/wiki/Speaker_of_the_United_States_House_of_Representatives
"Speaker of the United States House of Representatives"), [President pro
tempore of the Senate](/wiki/President_pro_tempore_of_the_United_States_Senate
"President pro tempore of the United States Senate"), and then the heads of
[federal executive
departments](/wiki/United_States_federal_executive_departments "United States
federal executive departments") who form the [Cabinet of the United
States](/wiki/Cabinet_of_the_United_States "Cabinet of the United States").
The Cabinet currently has fifteen members, beginning with the [Secretary of
State](/wiki/Secretary_of_State_of_the_United_States "Secretary of State of
the United States"), and followed by the rest in the order of their positions'
creation. Those heads of department who are ineligible to act as President are
also ineligible to succeed the President by succession, for example most
commonly if they are not a [natural-born U.S. citizen](/wiki/Natural-born-
citizen_clause "Natural-born-citizen clause").

Several constitutional law experts have raised questions as to the
constitutionality of the provisions that the Speaker of the House and the
President pro tempore of the Senate succeed to the presidency,[2] and in 2003
the [Continuity of Government
Commission](/wiki/Continuity_of_Government_Commission "Continuity of
Government Commission") raised a number of other issues with the current line
of succession.[3]

##
Eligibility[[edit](/w/index.php?title=United_States_presidential_line_of_succession&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Eligibility")]

### Eligibility
requirements[[edit](/w/index.php?title=United_States_presidential_line_of_succession&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Eligibility requirements")]

To be eligible to serve as President, a person must be a [natural-born U.S.
citizen](/wiki/Natural_born_citizen_of_the_United_States "Natural born citizen
of the United States"), at least 35 years of age, and a resident within the
United States for at least 14 years. These eligibility requirements are
specified both in the U.S. Constitution, Article II, Section 1, Clause 5, and
in the [Presidential Succession Act of 1947](/wiki/Presidential_Succession_Act
"Presidential Succession Act") ([3
U.S.C.](/wiki/Title_3_of_the_United_States_Code "Title 3 of the United States
Code") [§ 19(e)](https://www.law.cornell.edu/uscode/text/3/19#e)).

### Acting
officers[[edit](/w/index.php?title=United_States_presidential_line_of_succession&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Acting officers")]

[Acting](/wiki/Acting_\(law\) "Acting \(law\)") officers may be eligible. In
2009, the [Continuity of Government
Commission](/wiki/Continuity_of_Government_Commission "Continuity of
Government Commission"), a private [non-partisan](/wiki/Non-partisan "Non-
partisan") [think tank](/wiki/Think_tank "Think tank"), reported,

> The language in the current Presidential Succession Act is less clear than
> that of the 1886 Act with respect to Senate confirmation. The 1886 Act
> refers to "such officers as shall have been appointed by the advice and
> consent of the Senate to the office therein named..." The current act merely
> refers to "officers appointed, by and with the advice and consent of the
> Senate." Read literally, this means that the current act allows for acting
> secretaries to be in the line of succession as long as they are confirmed by
> the Senate for a post (even for example, the second or third in command
> within a department). It is common for a second in command to become acting
> secretary when the secretary leaves office. Though there is some dispute
> over this provision, the language clearly permits acting secretaries to be
> placed in the line of succession. (We have spoken to acting secretaries who
> told us they had been placed in the line of succession.)[5]

## Motivation for changes to the succession in
1945[[edit](/w/index.php?title=United_States_presidential_line_of_succession&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: Motivation for changes to the succession in 1945")]

Two months after succeeding [Franklin D.
Roosevelt](/wiki/Franklin_D._Roosevelt "Franklin D. Roosevelt"), President
[Harry S. Truman](/wiki/Harry_S._Truman "Harry S. Truman") proposed that the
[Speaker of the
House](/wiki/Speaker_of_the_United_States_House_of_Representatives "Speaker of
the United States House of Representatives") and the [President pro tempore of
the Senate](/wiki/President_pro_tempore_of_the_United_States_Senate "President
pro tempore of the United States Senate") be granted priority in the line of
succession over the [Cabinet](/wiki/Cabinet_of_the_United_States "Cabinet of
the United States") so as to ensure the President would not be able to appoint
his successor to the Presidency.[6]

The [Secretary of State](/wiki/United_States_Secretary_of_State "United States
Secretary of State") and the other [Cabinet
officials](/wiki/Cabinet_of_the_United_States "Cabinet of the United States")
are appointed by the President, while the Speaker of the House and the
President pro tempore of the Senate are elected officials. The Speaker is
chosen by the [U.S. House of
Representatives](/wiki/United_States_House_of_Representatives "United States
House of Representatives"), and every Speaker has been a member of that body
for the duration of their term as Speaker, though this is not technically a
requirement; the President pro tempore is chosen by the [U.S.
Senate](/wiki/United_States_Senate "United States Senate") and customarily the
Senator of the majority party with the longest record of continuous service
fills this position. The [Congress](/wiki/United_States_Congress "United
States Congress") approved this change and inserted the Speaker and President
pro tempore in line, ahead of the members of the Cabinet in the order in which
their positions were established.

In his speech supporting the changes, Truman noted that the House of
Representatives is more likely to be in political agreement with the President
and Vice President than the Senate. The succession of a Republican to a
Democratic Presidency would further complicate an already unstable political
situation. However, when the changes to the succession were signed into law,
they placed Republican House Speaker [Joseph W. Martin](/wiki/Joseph_W._Martin
"Joseph W. Martin") first in the line of succession after the Vice
President.[7]

Some of Truman's critics said that his ordering of the Speaker before the
President pro tempore was motivated by his dislike of the then-current holder
of the latter rank, Senator [Kenneth
McKellar](/wiki/Kenneth_McKellar_\(politician\) "Kenneth McKellar
\(politician\)").[8] Further motivation may have been provided by Truman's
preference for House Speaker [Sam Rayburn](/wiki/Sam_Rayburn "Sam Rayburn") to
be next in the line of succession, rather than Secretary of State [Edward R.
Stettinius, Jr.](/wiki/Edward_R._Stettinius,_Jr. "Edward R. Stettinius,
Jr.")[7]

## Constitutional
provisions[[edit](/w/index.php?title=United_States_presidential_line_of_succession&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: Constitutional provisions")]

The line of succession is mentioned in three places in the Constitution:

  * [Article II, Section 1, Clause 6](/wiki/Article_Two_of_the_United_States_Constitution#Clause_6:_Vacancy_and_disability "Article Two of the United States Constitution") makes the Vice President first in the line of succession and allows the [Congress](/wiki/United_States_Congress "United States Congress") to provide by law for cases in which neither the President nor Vice President can serve. The current such law governing succession is the [Presidential Succession Act of 1947](/wiki/Presidential_Succession_Act "Presidential Succession Act") ([3 U.S.C.](/wiki/Title_3_of_the_United_States_Code "Title 3 of the United States Code") [§ 19](https://www.law.cornell.edu/uscode/text/3/19)).
  * [Section 3 of the 20th Amendment](/wiki/Twentieth_Amendment_to_the_United_States_Constitution#Text "Twentieth Amendment to the United States Constitution") provides that if the [President-elect](/wiki/President-elect_of_the_United_States "President-elect of the United States") dies before his term begins, the Vice President-elect becomes President on [Inauguration Day](/wiki/United_States_presidential_inauguration "United States presidential inauguration") and serves for the full term to which the President-elect was elected. The section also provides that if, on Inauguration Day, a president has not been chosen or the President-elect does not qualify for the presidency, the Vice President-elect acts as president until a president is chosen or the President-elect qualifies. Finally, Section 3 allows the Congress to provide by law for cases in which neither a President-elect nor a Vice President-elect is eligible or available to serve.
  * The [25th Amendment](/wiki/Twenty-fifth_Amendment_to_the_United_States_Constitution "Twenty-fifth Amendment to the United States Constitution"), ratified in 1967, clarified Article II, Section 1: that the Vice President is the direct successor of the President. He or she becomes President if the President dies, resigns or is removed from office. The amendment also provides for the situation where the President is temporarily disabled, such as if the President has a surgical procedure or becomes mentally unfit.  
The amendment also provides for Vice Presidential succession, by requiring
Vice Presidential vacancies to be filled by the President and confirmed by
both houses of the Congress. Previously, whenever a Vice President had
succeeded to the Presidency or had otherwise left the office empty (through
death, resignation, or removal from office), the Vice Presidency remained
vacant until the next Presidential and Vice Presidential terms began.

## Acting President and
President[[edit](/w/index.php?title=United_States_presidential_line_of_succession&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: Acting President and President")]

Main article: [Acting President of the United
States](/wiki/Acting_President_of_the_United_States "Acting President of the
United States")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cc/Lyndon_B._Johnson_taking_the_oath_of_office%2C_November_1963.jpg/275px-
Lyndon_B._Johnson_taking_the_oath_of_office%2C_November_1963.jpg)](/wiki/File:Lyndon_B._Johnson_taking_the_oath_of_office,_November_1963.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Lyndon_B._Johnson_taking_the_oath_of_office,_November_1963.jpg
"Enlarge")

New President [Lyndon Johnson](/wiki/Lyndon_B._Johnson "Lyndon B. Johnson")
was [sworn in](/wiki/Oath_of_office_of_the_President_of_the_United_States
"Oath of office of the President of the United States") aboard [Air Force
One](/wiki/Air_Force_One "Air Force One"), following the [assassination
of](/wiki/John_F._Kennedy_assassination "John F. Kennedy assassination") [John
F. Kennedy](/wiki/John_F._Kennedy "John F. Kennedy") in 1963.

Article II, Section 1 of the United States Constitution provides that:

> In case of the removal of the President from office, or of his death,
> resignation, or inability to discharge the powers and duties of the said
> office, the same shall devolve on the Vice President ... until the
> disability be removed, or a President elected.

This originally left open the question whether "the same" refers to "the said
office" or only "the powers and duties of the said office." Some historians,
including [Edward Corwin](/wiki/Edward_Samuel_Corwin "Edward Samuel
Corwin")[9] and [John D. Feerick](/wiki/John_Feerick "John Feerick"),[9] have
argued that the framers' intention was that the Vice President would remain
Vice President while executing the powers and duties of the Presidency;
however, there is also much evidence to the contrary, the most compelling of
which is [Article I, section
3](/wiki/Article_One_of_the_United_States_Constitution#Section_3:_Senate
"Article One of the United States Constitution"), of the Constitution itself,
the relevant text of which reads:

> The Vice President of the United States shall be President of the Senate,
> but shall have no vote, unless they be equally divided.  
>  The Senate shall chuse [_[sic](/wiki/Sic "Sic")_] their other officers, and
> also a President pro tempore, in the absence of the Vice President, or when
> he shall **exercise** the **office of President** of the United States.

This text appears to answer the hypothetical question of whether the _office_
or merely the _powers_ of the Presidency devolved upon the Vice President on
his succession. Thus, the 25th Amendment merely restates and reaffirms the
validity of existing precedent, apart from adding new protocols for
Presidential disability.[_[original
research?](/wiki/Wikipedia:No_original_research "Wikipedia:No original
research")_] Not everyone agreed with this interpretation when it was first
actually tested, and it was left to Vice President [John
Tyler](/wiki/John_Tyler "John Tyler"), the first presidential successor in
U.S. history, to establish the precedent that was respected in the absence of
the 25th Amendment.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c5/John_Tyler.jpg/170px-
John_Tyler.jpg)](/wiki/File:John_Tyler.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:John_Tyler.jpg "Enlarge")

In 1841, [John Tyler](/wiki/John_Tyler "John Tyler") became the first person
to succeed to the presidency.

Upon the death of President [William Henry
Harrison](/wiki/William_Henry_Harrison "William Henry Harrison") in 1841 and
after a brief hesitation, Tyler took the position that he _was_ the President
and _not_ merely [acting
President](/wiki/Acting_President_of_the_United_States "Acting President of
the United States") upon taking the [presidential oath of
office](/wiki/Oath_of_office_of_the_President_of_the_United_States "Oath of
office of the President of the United States"). However, some
contempories—including [John Quincy Adams](/wiki/John_Quincy_Adams "John
Quincy Adams"),[9][10] Henry Clay[11] and other members of Congress[10][11]
Whig party leaders[11] and even Tyler's own cabinet[10][11]—believed that he
was only acting as President and did not have the office itself.

Nonetheless, Tyler adhered to his position, even returning, unopened, mail
addressed to the "Acting President of the United States" sent by his
detractors.[12] Tyler's view ultimately prevailed when the Senate voted to
accept the title "President,"[11] and this precedent was followed thereafter.
The question was finally resolved by Section 1 of the [25th
Amendment](/wiki/Twenty-fifth_Amendment_to_the_United_States_Constitution
"Twenty-fifth Amendment to the United States Constitution"), which specifies
that "In case of the removal of the President from office or of his death or
resignation, _the Vice President shall**become** President."_ The Amendment
does not specify whether officers other than the Vice President can become
President rather than Acting President in the same set of circumstances. The
[Presidential Succession Act](/wiki/Presidential_Succession_Act "Presidential
Succession Act") refers only to other officers acting as President rather than
becoming President.

## History of succession law set by
Congress[[edit](/w/index.php?title=United_States_presidential_line_of_succession&action=edit&section=8
"Edit section: History of succession law set by Congress")]

### Presidential Succession Act
1792[[edit](/w/index.php?title=United_States_presidential_line_of_succession&action=edit&section=9
"Edit section: Presidential Succession Act 1792")]

Main article: [Presidential Succession Act](/wiki/Presidential_Succession_Act
"Presidential Succession Act")

![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/Wikisource-logo.svg/38px-Wikisource-logo.svg.png) | [Wikisource](/wiki/Wikisource "Wikisource") has original text related to this article: **[Presidential Succession Act 1792](https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Presidential_Succession_Act_1792 "wikisource:Presidential Succession Act 1792")**  
---|---  
  
The [Presidential Succession Act of
1792](/wiki/Presidential_Succession_Act#After_the_Presidential_Succession_Act_of_1792
"Presidential Succession Act") was the first succession law passed by
Congress. The act was contentious because the
[Federalists](/wiki/Federalist_Party "Federalist Party") did not want the then
Secretary of State, [Thomas Jefferson](/wiki/Thomas_Jefferson "Thomas
Jefferson"), who had become the leader of the [Democratic-
Republicans](/wiki/Democratic-Republican_Party "Democratic-Republican Party"),
to follow the Vice President in the succession. There were also [separation of
powers](/wiki/Separation_of_powers "Separation of powers") concerns over
including the [Chief Justice of the United
States](/wiki/Chief_Justice_of_the_United_States "Chief Justice of the United
States") in the line. The compromise they worked out established the President
pro tempore of the Senate as next in line after the Vice President, followed
by the Speaker of the House of Representatives.

In either case, these officers were to "act as President of the United States
until the disability be removed or a president be elected." The Act called for
a special election to be held in November of the year in which dual vacancies
occurred (unless the vacancies occurred after the first Wednesday in October,
in which case the election would occur the following year; or unless the
vacancies occurred within the last year of the presidential term, in which
case the next election would take place as regularly scheduled). The people
elected President and Vice President in such a special election would have
served a full four-year term beginning on March 4 of the next year, but no
such election ever took place.

### Presidential Succession Act
1886[[edit](/w/index.php?title=United_States_presidential_line_of_succession&action=edit&section=10
"Edit section: Presidential Succession Act 1886")]

![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/Wikisource-logo.svg/38px-Wikisource-logo.svg.png) | [Wikisource](/wiki/Wikisource "Wikisource") has original text related to this article: **[Presidential Succession Act 1886](https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Presidential_Succession_Act_1886 "wikisource:Presidential Succession Act 1886")**  
---|---  
  
In 1881, after the death of President [Garfield](/wiki/James_A._Garfield
"James A. Garfield"), and in 1885, after the death of Vice President
[Hendricks](/wiki/Thomas_A._Hendricks "Thomas A. Hendricks"), there had been
no President pro tempore in office, and as the new House of Representatives
had yet to convene, no Speaker either,[13] leaving no one at all in the line
of succession after the vice president. When Congress convened in December
1885, President [Cleveland](/wiki/Grover_Cleveland "Grover Cleveland") asked
for a revision of the 1792 act, which was passed in 1886. Congress replaced
the President pro tempore and Speaker with officers of the President's
[Cabinet](/wiki/United_States_Cabinet "United States Cabinet") with the
Secretary of State first in line. In the first 100 years of the United States,
six former [Secretaries of State](/wiki/United_States_Secretary_of_State
"United States Secretary of State") had gone on to be elected President, while
only two congressional leaders had advanced to that office. As a result,
changing the order of the line of succession seemed reasonable.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

### Presidential Succession Act
1947[[edit](/w/index.php?title=United_States_presidential_line_of_succession&action=edit&section=11
"Edit section: Presidential Succession Act 1947")]

![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/Wikisource-logo.svg/38px-Wikisource-logo.svg.png) | [Wikisource](/wiki/Wikisource "Wikisource") has original text related to this article: **[Presidential Succession Act 1947](https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Presidential_Succession_Act_1947 "wikisource:Presidential Succession Act 1947")**  
---|---  
  
The [Presidential Succession Act of
1947](/wiki/Presidential_Succession_Act#After_the_Presidential_Succession_Act_of_1947
"Presidential Succession Act"), signed into law by President [Harry S.
Truman](/wiki/Harry_S._Truman "Harry S. Truman"), added the Speaker of the
House and President pro tempore back in the line, but switched the two from
the 1792 order. It remains the sequence used
today[[update]](//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=United_States_presidential_line_of_succession&action=edit).
Since the reorganization of the military in 1947 had merged the War Department
(which governed the Army) with the Department of the Navy into the [Department
of Defense](/wiki/United_States_Department_of_Defense "United States
Department of Defense"), the Secretary of Defense took the place in the order
of succession previously held by the Secretary of War. The office of
[Secretary of the Navy](/wiki/United_States_Secretary_of_the_Navy "United
States Secretary of the Navy"), which had existed as a Cabinet-level position
since 1798, had become subordinate to the Secretary of Defense in the military
reorganization, and so was dropped from the line of succession in the 1947
Succession Act.

### Postmaster General removed
1971[[edit](/w/index.php?title=United_States_presidential_line_of_succession&action=edit&section=12
"Edit section: Postmaster General removed 1971")]

Until 1971, the [Postmaster General](/wiki/United_States_Postmaster_General
"United States Postmaster General"), the head of the [Post Office
Department](/wiki/United_States_Post_Office_Department "United States Post
Office Department"), was a member of the [Cabinet](/wiki/United_States_Cabinet
"United States Cabinet"), initially the last in the presidential line of
succession before new officers were added. Once the Post Office Department was
re-organized into the [United States Postal
Service](/wiki/United_States_Postal_Service "United States Postal Service"), a
special agency independent of the executive branch, the Postmaster General
ceased to be a member of the Cabinet and was thus removed from the line of
succession.[14]

### Secretary of Homeland Security added
2006[[edit](/w/index.php?title=United_States_presidential_line_of_succession&action=edit&section=13
"Edit section: Secretary of Homeland Security added 2006")]

The [United States Department of Homeland
Security](/wiki/United_States_Department_of_Homeland_Security "United States
Department of Homeland Security") was created in 2002. On March 9, 2006,
pursuant to the renewal of the Patriot Act as [Pub.L.
109–177](http://legislink.org/us/pl-109-177), the Secretary of Homeland
Security was added to the line of succession. The order of Cabinet members in
the line has always been the same as the order in which their respective
departments were established. Despite custom, many in Congress had wanted the
Secretary to be placed at number eight on the list – below the Attorney
General, above the Secretary of the Interior, and in the position held by the
Secretary of the Navy prior to the creation of the Secretary of Defense –
because the Secretary, already in charge of disaster relief and security,
would presumably be more prepared to take over the presidency than some of the
other Cabinet secretaries.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] Despite this, the 2006 law explicitly specifies
that the "Secretary of Homeland Security" follows the "Secretary of Veterans
Affairs" in the succession, effectively at the end of the list.[15]

## Successions beyond Vice
President[[edit](/w/index.php?title=United_States_presidential_line_of_succession&action=edit&section=14
"Edit section: Successions beyond Vice President")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/41/Atchison_David_Rice_-
_Plattsburg_MO_3.jpg/275px-Atchison_David_Rice_-
_Plattsburg_MO_3.jpg)](/wiki/File:Atchison_David_Rice_-_Plattsburg_MO_3.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Atchison_David_Rice_-_Plattsburg_MO_3.jpg "Enlarge")

[David Rice Atchison](/wiki/David_Rice_Atchison "David Rice Atchison")'s
tombstone (Plattsburg, Missouri), including the claim "President of the United
States for One Day"

While nine Vice Presidents have succeeded to the office upon the death or
resignation of the President, and two Vice Presidents have temporarily served
as acting President, no other officer has ever been called upon to act as
President. On March 4, 1849, President [Zachary Taylor](/wiki/Zachary_Taylor
"Zachary Taylor")'s term began, but he declined to be sworn in on a Sunday,
citing religious beliefs, and the Vice President was not sworn either. As the
last President _pro tempore_ of the Senate, [David Rice
Atchison](/wiki/David_Rice_Atchison "David Rice Atchison") was thought by some
to be next in line after the Vice President, and his tombstone claims that he
was US President for the day. However, Atchison took no oath of office to the
presidency either, and his term as Senate President _pro tempore_ had by then
expired.[16][17]

In 1865, when [Andrew Johnson](/wiki/Andrew_Johnson "Andrew Johnson") assumed
the Presidency on the death of [Abraham Lincoln](/wiki/Abraham_Lincoln
"Abraham Lincoln"), the office of Vice President became vacant. At that time,
the Senate President pro tempore was next in line to the presidency. In 1868,
[Johnson was impeached](/wiki/Impeachment_of_Andrew_Johnson "Impeachment of
Andrew Johnson") by the House of Representatives and subjected to trial in the
Senate, and if he had been convicted and thereby removed from office, Senate
President pro tempore [Benjamin Wade](/wiki/Benjamin_Wade "Benjamin Wade")
would have become acting President. This posed a conflict of interest, as
Wade's "guilty" vote could have been decisive in removing Johnson from office
and giving himself presidential powers and duties. (Johnson was acquitted by a
one-vote margin.)

In his book _The Shadow Presidents,_ which he published in 1979, [Michael
Medved](/wiki/Michael_Medved "Michael Medved") describes a situation that
arose prior to the [1916
election](/wiki/United_States_presidential_election,_1916 "United States
presidential election, 1916"), when the [First World War](/wiki/World_War_I
"World War I") was raging in Europe. In view of the contemporary international
turmoil, [President Woodrow Wilson](/wiki/Woodrow_Wilson "Woodrow Wilson")
thought that if he lost the election it would be better for his opponent to
begin his administration straight away, instead of waiting through the [lame
duck](/wiki/Lame_duck_\(politics\)#United_States "Lame duck \(politics\)")
period, which at that time had a duration of almost four months. President
Wilson and his aides formed a plan to exploit the rule of succession so that
his rival [Charles Evans Hughes](/wiki/Charles_Evans_Hughes "Charles Evans
Hughes") could take over the Presidency as soon as the result of the election
was clear. The plan was that Wilson would appoint Hughes to the post of
[Secretary of State](/wiki/U.S._Secretary_of_State "U.S. Secretary of State").
Wilson and his Vice President [Thomas R. Marshall](/wiki/Thomas_R._Marshall
"Thomas R. Marshall") would then resign, and as the Secretary of State was at
that time designated next in line of succession, Hughes would become President
immediately. As it happened, President Wilson won re-election, so the plan was
never put into action.[18]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/53/Ford_sworn-
in.jpg/275px-Ford_sworn-in.jpg)](/wiki/File:Ford_sworn-in.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Ford_sworn-in.jpg "Enlarge")

New President [Gerald Ford](/wiki/Gerald_Ford "Gerald Ford") is sworn in
following the resignation of [Richard Nixon](/wiki/Richard_Nixon "Richard
Nixon") on August 9, 1974.

Since the 25th Amendment's ratification, its [Second Section](/wiki/Twenty-
fifth_Amendment_to_the_United_States_Constitution#Section_2:_Vice_Presidential_vacancy
"Twenty-fifth Amendment to the United States Constitution"), which addresses
Vice Presidential succession as noted above, has been invoked twice.

During the [1973 Vice Presidential
vacancy](/wiki/Spiro_Agnew#Criminal_investigation_and_resignation "Spiro
Agnew"), [House
Speaker](/wiki/Speaker_of_the_United_States_House_of_Representatives "Speaker
of the United States House of Representatives") [Carl
Albert](/wiki/Carl_Albert "Carl Albert") was first in line. As the [Watergate
scandal](/wiki/Watergate_scandal "Watergate scandal") made President Nixon's
removal or resignation possible, Albert would have become [Acting
President](/wiki/Acting_President_of_the_United_States "Acting President of
the United States") and—under Title 3, Section 19(c) of the [U.S.
Code](/wiki/United_States_Code "United States Code")—would have been able to
"act as President until the expiration of the then current Presidential term"
on January 20, 1977. Albert openly questioned whether it was appropriate for
him, a [Democrat](/wiki/Democratic_Party_\(United_States\) "Democratic Party
\(United States\)"), to assume the powers and duties of the presidency when
there was a public [mandate](/wiki/Mandate_\(politics\) "Mandate
\(politics\)") for the Presidency to be held by a
[Republican](/wiki/Republican_Party_\(United_States\) "Republican Party
\(United States\)"). Albert announced that should he need to assume the
Presidential powers and duties, he would do so only as a
[caretaker](/wiki/Caretaker_government "Caretaker government"). However, with
the nomination and confirmation of [Gerald Ford](/wiki/Gerald_Ford "Gerald
Ford") to the Vice Presidency, which marked the first time the [Second
Section](/wiki/Twenty-
fifth_Amendment_to_the_United_States_Constitution#Section_2:_Vice_Presidential_vacancy
"Twenty-fifth Amendment to the United States Constitution") of the Twenty-
fifth Amendment was invoked, these series of events were never tested. Albert
again became first-in-line during the first four months of Ford's Presidency,
before the confirmation of Vice President [Nelson
Rockefeller](/wiki/Nelson_Rockefeller "Nelson Rockefeller"),[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] which
marked the second time Section 2 of the Twenty-fifth Amendment was invoked.

In 1981, when [President Ronald Reagan was
shot](/wiki/Reagan_assassination_attempt "Reagan assassination attempt"), Vice
President [George H. W. Bush](/wiki/George_H._W._Bush "George H. W. Bush") was
traveling in Texas. Secretary of State [Alexander Haig](/wiki/Alexander_Haig
"Alexander Haig") responded to a reporter's question regarding who was running
the government by stating:

> Constitutionally, gentlemen, you have the President, the Vice President and
> the Secretary of State in that order, and should the President decide he
> wants to transfer the helm to the Vice President, he will do so. He has not
> done that. As of now, I am in control here, in the White House, pending
> return of the Vice President and in close touch with him. If something came
> up, I would check with him, of course.[19]

A bitter dispute ensued over the meaning of Haig's remarks. Most people
believed that Haig was referring to the line of succession and erroneously
claimed to have temporary Presidential authority, due to his implied reference
to the Constitution. Haig and his supporters, noting his familiarity with the
line of succession from his time as [White House Chief of
Staff](/wiki/White_House_Chief_of_Staff "White House Chief of Staff") during
[Richard Nixon](/wiki/Richard_Nixon "Richard Nixon")'s resignation, said he
only meant that he was the highest-ranking officer of the [Executive
branch](/wiki/Federal_government_of_the_United_States#Executive_branch
"Federal government of the United States") on-site, managing things
temporarily until the Vice President returned to
[Washington](/wiki/Washington,_D.C. "Washington, D.C.").[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

## Constitutional
concerns[[edit](/w/index.php?title=United_States_presidential_line_of_succession&action=edit&section=15
"Edit section: Constitutional concerns")]

Several constitutional law experts have raised questions as to the
constitutionality of the provisions that the Speaker of the House and the
President pro tempore of the Senate succeed to the presidency.[20] [James
Madison](/wiki/James_Madison "James Madison"), one of the authors of the
Constitution, raised similar constitutional questions about the [Presidential
Succession Act of
1792](/wiki/Presidential_Succession_Act#After_the_Presidential_Succession_Act_of_1792
"Presidential Succession Act") in a 1792 letter to [Edmund
Pendleton](/wiki/Edmund_Pendleton "Edmund Pendleton").[21] Two of these issues
can be summarized:

  * The term "Officer" in the relevant clause of the Constitution is most plausibly interpreted to mean an "[Officer of the United States](/wiki/Officer_of_the_United_States "Officer of the United States")", who must be a member of the Executive or Judicial Branch. The Speaker and the President pro tempore are not officers in this sense.
  * Under the principle of separation of powers, the Constitution specifically disallows legislative officials from also serving in the executive branch. For the Speaker or the Senate President pro tempore to become Acting President, they must resign their position, at which point they are no longer in the line of succession. This is seen by some to form a constitutional [paradox](/wiki/Paradox "Paradox"). However, the current Act specifies that the Speaker becomes President "upon his resignation as Speaker" and as a member of Congress,[22] allowing for a seamless transition.

In 2003 the [Continuity of Government
Commission](/wiki/Continuity_of_Government_Commission "Continuity of
Government Commission") suggested that the current law has "at least seven
significant issues ... that warrant attention", specifically:[23]

  1. The reality that all figures in the current line of succession work and reside in the vicinity of Washington, D.C. In the event of a nuclear, chemical, or biological attack, it is possible that everyone on the list would be killed or incapacitated.
  2. Doubt (such as those expressed above by James Madison) that congressional leaders are eligible to act as President.
  3. A concern about the wisdom of including the President pro tempore in the line of succession as the "largely honorific post traditionally held by the longest-serving Senator of the majority party". For example, from January 20, 2001, to June 6, 2001, the President pro tempore was then-98-year-old [Strom Thurmond](/wiki/Strom_Thurmond "Strom Thurmond") of [South Carolina](/wiki/South_Carolina "South Carolina").
  4. A concern that the current line of succession can force the presidency to abruptly switch parties mid-term, as the President, Speaker, and the President pro tempore are not necessarily of the same party as each other.
  5. A concern that the succession line is ordered by the dates of creation of the various executive departments, without regard to the skills or capacities of the persons serving as their Secretary.
  6. The fact that, should a [Cabinet](/wiki/United_States_Cabinet "United States Cabinet") member begin to act as President, the law allows the [House](/wiki/United_States_House_of_Representatives "United States House of Representatives") to elect a new Speaker (or the [Senate](/wiki/United_States_Senate "United States Senate"), a new President pro tempore), who could in effect remove the Cabinet member and assume the office themselves at any time.
  7. The absence of a provision where a President is disabled and the vice presidency is vacant (for example, if an assassination attempt simultaneously wounded the President and killed the Vice President).

  * [Secretary of Homeland Security](/wiki/United_States_Secretary_of_Homeland_Security "United States Secretary of Homeland Security") ([Kirstjen Nielsen](/wiki/Kirstjen_Nielsen "Kirstjen Nielsen"))

  
  
  1. **Jump up ^** Never confirmed by and with the [advice and consent](/wiki/Advice_and_consent "Advice and consent") of the [Senate](/wiki/United_States_Senate "United States Senate") and thus [ineligible for the presidential line of succession](/wiki/United_States_presidential_line_of_succession#Acting_officers "United States presidential line of succession").
  2. **Jump up ^** Although [Elaine Chao](/wiki/Elaine_Chao "Elaine Chao") is the current Secretary of Transportation, she is not a [natural-born citizen](/wiki/Natural-born-citizen_clause "Natural-born-citizen clause") (acquired U.S. citizenship by naturalization) and thus [ineligible for the Presidency](/wiki/Article_Two_of_the_United_States_Constitution#Clause_5:_Qualifications_for_office "Article Two of the United States Constitution").
